case_vignette: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an episode of hemoptysis. He has a chronic cough that is productive of copious sputum. Six years ago, he had a stroke that left him with difficulty swallowing. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years, but quit 2 years ago. His respirations are 25/min and labored. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. An x-ray of the chest shows tram track opacities in the lower lung fields.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I am experiencing coughing up blood, difficulty swallowing, and labored breathing.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I have had a chronic cough producing a lot of mucus for a long time, and the difficulty in swallowing started six years ago. The coughing up of blood started more recently.
Do you have any history of smoking or exposure to hazardous substances?
Yes, I smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 2 years ago.
Have you had any recent weight loss or night sweats?
No, I have not experienced recent weight loss or night sweats.
Do you have any history of cancer in your family?
I am not aware of any history of cancer in my family.
Have you ever had any previous medical imaging done, like a chest X-ray or CT scan? If yes, what were the results?
Yes, I had a chest X-ray done recently which showed tram track opacities in the lower lung fields.
Final Diagnosis: Bronchiectasis
